fdd:identificationAndDescription.fdd:description: Bitstream encoding for video; John McGowan states, "Cinepak uses Vector Quantization based image compression and frame differencing." Multiple versions exist, including "SuperMac," "Radius," and "Compression Technologies;" this document does not distinguish between them.
fdd:identificationAndDescription.fdd:shortDescription: Bitstream encoding for video using Vector Quantization methods for image compression and frame differencing.
fdd:identificationAndDescription.fdd:productionPhase: May be used as a middle-state (video production) or end-user delivery format.

fdd:sustainabilityFactors.fdd:disclosure: Proprietary standard with little or no public documentation
fdd:sustainabilityFactors.fdd:adoption: Has been widespread; in 2000, John McGowan wrote that "Cinepak is the most widely used Video for Windows codec."
fdd:sustainabilityFactors.fdd:licensingAndPatents: Apparently various providers of encoders license the use of their products.
fdd:sustainabilityFactors.fdd:transparency: Depends upon algorithms and tools to read; will require sophistication to build tools.
fdd:sustainabilityFactors.fdd:selfDocumentation: Not applicable; provided by wrapper formats.
fdd:sustainabilityFactors.fdd:techProtection: Not applicable; provided by wrapper formats.

fdd:movingImageQF.fdd:clarity: Moderate, varies according to encoder used.

fdd:values.fdd:note: Used when this codec is wrapped in Microsoft file formats, e.g., AVI and ASF; see the list of FOURCC codes. FOURCC codes are no longer managed by Microsoft, which has developed a new mechanism for identifying rich media types in general.

fdd:notes.fdd:general: Some discussion of Cinepak in John McGowan's AVI Overview: Audio and Video Codecs (http://www.jmcgowan.com/avicodecs.html).
